text: the Landau family is building a second
home in Central Vermont a home in
Vermont without a furnace on the first
floor we have dining living room in
kitchen all the windows here on the
south side it's extra one here at the
end of the hallway they hope the new
homes southern exposure
combined with a few other attributes
will make it a certified passive home
common in Europe but rare in the United
States
passive homes are so thoroughly
insulated and so tightly sealed that
they require minimal heat even here in
Chile New England
I remember reading a book about a
building engineer in England who
designed and built a house which was
only needed by his tea kettle and the
his buddies he brought over to have a
party and drink some beer so just the
idea that and it was so insulated it
could keep warm with just the oven the
cooktop and the bodies inside I thought
that was really fascinating idea the
Landau's who currently live in suburban
Boston say that finding the materials
and expertise to build a passive house
in this country was initially
challenging not even their friends
understood what they were trying to do
and they say what's the point why would
you do something different because
everybody else has six-inch studs seem
to be fine for everybody else you can
buy good one double pane windows and I
said it just doesn't compare it really
doesn't conventional homes can use up to
90% more heating and cooling energy than
passive homes but passive homes do cost
more in Europe the additional cost can
be as little as 2 to 3%
but in the u.s. without an established
supply chain it's much higher we think
that the cost here is going to be 15 to
20 percent more than our standard
because it's thicker it's more
insulation there's a little more in the
layers so there's a little more labour
Ted Benson a New Hampshire based builder
is part of the team of architects and
other contractors the land house hired
to build and design their home Benson's
crew assembles the thick walls and
specialty windows of the Landau's home
in a warehouse but the requirements of
the Passivhaus certification have made
some of the family's wishes impractical
being up in Vermont coming in from a
cold snowy day you'd want it's nice to
have a stove they heat up the house and
to sit in front of and if even if it's
just for psychological reasons we wanted
to have that and we were told oh no it's
gonna heat up the house way too much
that won't work
then someone suggests they could just
open a window if things got too hot on a
winter day after nearly a year the
foundation and central beams and walls
rise compared to building a conventional
home the Landau's estimate it will cost
an additional $50,000 to build to the
passive standard at current heating fuel
prices they could earn that back in ten
years you don't want to be reliant on
imported oil to eat our house it makes
so much sense if they have a long-term
view there it's surprising that it's
considered anything different or unusual
here it shouldn't be it should be
standard
